"Maybe, I could take this opportunity to become Michelle, and have a better shot at being closer to John..."

She smiled at the thought of a better relationship between he and herself. So, she took it, right then and there.

"I wish I could become Michelle Cooke, the girlfriend of my son, John Robinson." Jenna wished, stone in hand. The stone gave a bright shine, Jenna shut her eyes, calmly, and the changes began.

Jenna first shrunk in height from her usual 5'9" to a small and cute 5'2". While her height decreased, her age did also, drastically regressing from her 37 year old womanly self, to Michelle's age of a 14 year old teenage girl. Also during the height change, her body grew smaller and more youthful looking. On her face, all signs of age faded, and she had a much revitalized look. Her dark brown hair changed into light brown hair and changed itself into a ponytail Michelle would always have. Her eye color from brown to blue. Her business like suit began to change also. Her skirt grew smaller and showed off more leg, the skirt also changed from a dull brown to a forest green. Her shirt went from a buttoned up business shirt to a pink T-shirt. Her heels, they changed into flats. On her wrist grew a simply designed solid pink bracelet. Finally she was done. Physically, no longer was she the 37 year old woman known as Jenna Robinson. Now, she was the 14 year old high school freshman girl, Michelle Cole.

"This is nice," Michelle said in her new voice, in a content tone, happy with her new body, examining herself, pulling out a mirror from her backpack, which had also transformed from her purse, and looking at her face. She was gorgeous, a very pretty teenage girl. After scanning her now very attractive legs, shown off by her new skirt, she smiled contently and observed other changes.

She pulled out her former purse, now her backpack and looked at it's contents. Inside was a one-piece bathing suit, and instead of what was usually kept in her purse, there were binders, books, pencils and pens, and a picture of Michelle, now herself, and her son, now her boyfriend, John. For some strange reason, to her, she felt a warmth in looking at the picture.

From there, she decided to head over to the school's cafeteria to find her son, or boyfriend, in this case.

Jenna grabbed for her new backpack, placed it on her back, made sure she had the necklace and stone on her neck, and proceeded to the cafeteria to find John.

She walked right on in, noticing many of the male students 'checking her out' discretely, but failing, for she noticed and felt their eyes all over her. Though, she payed it no mind, it was actually a confidence booster, she blushed heavily and continued on, remembering that her physical form was taken, but, on the inside, she herself loved it. Attention was one thing that Jenna never got, and, though she was being checked out by teenage boys, she felt awesome, as strange as it sounded.

She walked on and finally entered the cafeteria, once there, she stared in awe. It was like a jungle, it was incredibly loud, and with all the students there, her looking upon them all, felt as of she was staring into a sea.

"How am I gonna find John in this crowd of people?" She thought. Though, it seemed as if it'd take forever, Jenna caught him alone, sitting at a table close by, away from the sea of students. This brought her great happiness, and she calmly strutted over to him, as his girlfriend.

John looked over and noticed his girlfriend, or mother, approaching him. His face quickly lit up with happiness, a huge smile coming over his face.

"Baby!" John exclaimed. "I thought you were gonna be absent or something today!" He exclaimed, rushing over to give his girlfriend a huge hug and a peck on her cheek.

"Hey, John!" Jenna exclaimed, again, heavily blushing. It felt amazing, this was the first time in a while that she's ever gotten any affection from John. The only, downside to her, was that he wasn't really showing affection to his mother, herself, bu to his girlfriend. "Any affection is better than none!" Jenna confirmed, embracing her 'boyfriend' in a hug as well.

"So how ya doing, babe?" John happily asked, a mood Jenna has never seen him in.

"Pretty good, how about you?" Jenna replied.

"Great now that you're here!"

This caused Jenna to blush some more.

After this greeting, the two, John and 'Michelle,' walked over to a table while John began to talk about this and that. From the text language, Jenna found herself even more confused when he went on, speaking of all these artists she's not once heard of. He spoke of these artists, their new singles and all that. 1321112112121.content:
Jenna scanned the group of cheerleaders, attempting to quickly come to a decision as to who, exactly, she would become. Jenna knew she wouldn't get in the school in her current motherly form. At least not without looking blatantly out of place. A full grown woman, not of a staff member, wandering about the school, looking for her son, a rather young student.

"Not only out of place..." Jenna started, "But a perv also..."

Jenna had no time to be picky, time wouldn't allow this. Surely, the bell would ring within minutes. Just then, she noticed a group of about five cheerleaders, donning the light-blue and white colored uniforms, complete with matching skirt and white tennis shoes, beginning to make their way into the school. Among them, she recognized two of them. One of the girls whom she recognized was a cute, young girl, a freshman her son's age by the name of Lucy Gibbons. She only recognized Ms. Gibbons because Lucy was the daughter of Elizabeth, or 'Liz,' Gibbons, one of Jenna's closer friends and a co-worker. Considering the few conversations Jenna and Lucy had , Jenna knew Lucy to be a good, kind person.

The other girl Jenna recognized was a girl named Abby Watson. Jenna only recognized Abby because Abby was the daughter of her boss, a man by the name of Richard Watson. Mr. Watson, believe it or not, was not a bad person, but rather the opposite. However, despite his good, upbeat nature, he was a man and father who spoiled his daughters and wife. Having met his wife and two daughters, among them, Abby, you concluded that they were indeed spoiled, to the point of a bitter, snooty personality in Abby. But, unlike her personality, Abby was definitely a good-looking young woman.

Quickly, Jenna made her decision. "I wish I, Jenna Robinson, was the twin sister of Lucy Gibbons!"

Suddenly, unlike the other time Jenna had changed, this one was very quick. Jenna hardly felt anything, physically. The only thing that was painfully obvious upon her wish was that she had transported, with the blink of an eye, from the inside of her car to among the group of cheerleaders she just witnessed. In shock she looked down at herself, and, as expected, she donned the cheerleading uniform of her son's alma mater. She looked down and noticed, her legs were more youthful and lighter in color. She looked ahead and also noticed that she was significantly shorter. She reached for her purse, but, instead, found the purse had become a backpack. When she opened it, she realized that, along with school supplies and various books, also in the bag were belongings she also had in her purse. From the bag, she pulled a mirror. "Wow..." She said in her new voice, hardly noticing any difference between her new voice and that of Lucy's. In the mirror, was the spitting image, the very clone of Lucy Gibbons.

"Wow. Just wow." Jenna awed, truly amazed by what the stone had done.

Abruptly, the call of a voice caught her attention. "Jen! Sis! C'mon! We're gonna be late! You know how much a pain in the ass Mr. Reed can be!" Lucy called.

"Coming... Sis?!" Jenna nervously replied, hesitating in referring to Lucy as your sister, again, noting the striking similarities in your voices. Jenna grabbed her backpack and ran for the door.

"Just made it" Lucy said to Jenna as the two entered the classroom as the bell was ringing. Most of the seats were already occupied by other ninth grade students. Lucy took an empty seat on the third row, and Jenna took another empty set to the left. Jenna discretely looked around her for John, although she knew he wasn't there. She knew for a fact that John was part of Mr. Reed's fourth hour class.

About thirty seconds later, David Reed, the 9th grade World History teacher, entered the room. The fifty-two year old man with white hair and glasses looked at the twins. "Lucy and Jennifer Gibbons, on time for once" he said sarcastically before he began his lecture on Egyptian history.

Jenna took a notebook and pencil from her backpack and tried to pretend to listen to the lecture. Her mind was occupied with how to find her 'son'. She recalled that John and Lucy both had Mr. James Stevans Mathematics class in the second period. She then remembered that her Mom (Elizabeth Gibbons) had arraigned for her twin daughters to have the same schedule. Jenna rubbed her head, slightly disoriented by memories from two different universes.

The lecture continued until about fifteen minutes before the hour, when Mr. Reed suddenly stopped and said. "So, let's have a pop quiz?" Most of the students groaned at the announcement. Mr. Reed was notorious for having surprise tests near the end of the period.

Jenna had a near panic attack as she examined at the paper handed to her. There were fifteen questions and she didn't know the answers to any of them. Without thinking she whispered, "I wish I knew the answers". She looked at the questions again and she knew what the answers were. She quickly glanced at a nervous Lucy and wished her twin sister would also know the answers. Jenna confidently marked the answers on her test and finished with a minute to spare.

"Time's up" Mr. Reed announced and called for the papers. Jenna passed her quiz paper to the classmate in front of her. After Reed gave the class their assignments for the rest of the week, Jenna took her bag and left the classroom with Lucy.

"How did you do, Jen?" Lucy asked.

"I think I did OK"

"I thought I was going to flunk that quiz" Lucy exclaimed, "then I remembered the answers. It was so weird."

"Guess we were lucky" Jenna smiled, knowing why they aced the pop quiz.

The twins walked down the corridor to Mr. Stevans’ math class. Jenna took her seat waiting for her son to walk in.

1321112112121112.content:
Jenna sat there in her desk, idle. She examined the classroom around her, and, my, how the times had changed. When she herself had attended high school, the students had, well, respect. Now, they ran about in a chaotic manner. "Now..." Jenna thought, straightening out the folds on the skirt of her cheer leading uniform, "...They're more hoodlums than students." The students fidgeted with their iPods and iPads, mostly playing games of all sorts, probably not considering the power, or price, of the technology they played with as a toy. This was the Jenna Robinson side of Jenna's mind talking.

Then, with no warning, Jenna felt compelled to pull out her own iPod, which she knew was in the right-side pocket of her backpack. Jenna Robinson, 35 year old woman and mother, had not the slightest idea of how to work these things, but, Jenna Gibbons, 15 year old girl and student knew exactly how to work it. Jenna Robinson wanted to put the device away, but Jenna Gibbons felt the desire to have her go at a game. The Gibbons side of Jenna's brain won this struggle, and, before you knew it, Jenna played that game as an expert would. Eventually, the Robinson side of Jenna's mind got the better half and put the thing away.

"Oh my god!" Exclaimed Jenna in mind. "What the hell is happening?! I'm... I'm losing my mind! It must be, like, the body!" Jenna thought, not noticing the slight change in her speech/thought patterns.

Suddenly, the chaos in her mind was broken when John Robinson, her son, entered the room.

"This is it!" Jenna Robinson smiled, delighted at the thought of speaking with her son, the whole reason she became this girl in the first place. "I can finally talk to my son! At last!" Jenna chirped in her mind, getting ready to get up to walk to her son. Just then, a thought caused her to take her seat again. "Wait... How can I have a son? I'm only 15!" Jenna Gibbons thought. Jenna shook out these thoughts and, again, only got slightly lifted off of her seat, when the Jenna Gibbons portion of her mind questioned "Why?"

"I have to see John! He's my son!" Jenna Robinson exclaimed in mind.

"No!" Jenna Gibbons fought, "I don't have a son! I'm not a mother!"

"Yes! Yes I am a mother!"

"No I'm not! I'm just a 15 year old girl!"

"... 35 year old woman!"

The struggle continued. Until..

"Youth..." Jenna sighed in the dreamiest of ways. "Innocence..." She sighed in a manner similar to her previous statement. Becoming a high school student would certainly be enjoyable to her, no doubt. But, it was then that she came to a disenchanting realization about teenage life.

"Teachers..." She truly hated staff and faculty as a student. 'Foul,' was the only adjective that came to mind whence she thought of teachers. Other description for the teachers she worked under may have been 'rude,' 'condescending,' or just plain full of it. She didn't even think them 'normal,' citizens of society, and found it all too abnormal when she sighted one of her instructors outside of school.

But, as much as she disliked teachers, they did have one thing that she would never have in any teenage form she might pick. "Power. Authority!" She said, defeated, having become accustomed to the thought of becoming a student. "But, hey, maybe I'll enjoy it... Plus, it's not about me, it's about John." Jenna pronounced while pulling into the teachers parking lot. Jenna was a 'glass-half-full' kind of woman, and welcomed whatever circumstances she was presented with, liking them or not.

Having parked her car as far away from others as possible, dear Jenna found herself presented with another obstacle.

"Who to become..." She mumbled, scratching her chin lightly.

She looked out to the lot and scanned over the teachers entering their workplace, men and women alike.

"What gender?" She asked, examining the 'options' of forms to take on.

Then she came to the female teacher. Still looking at things from a student's standpoint, she came to a few realizations about women teachers. The female teacher possessed a particular charm, a softness, a kindness not found in a male teacher. And, while male teachers were just fine to look at, a woman teacher was just stunning in appearance, and, considering her son was, indeed, a boy, he'd definitely prefer a female teacher.

One of the teachers Jenna recognized as a particular Ms. Melanie Carmichael, 23 years old and semi-fresh out of college, this year being her second year of teaching. 1321112211221.content:
Being ready to finally unleash the power of the stone she held in her delicate hands, Jenna excitedly made her wish.

"I wish that John and I will be able to, someway, somehow, be able to spend more quality time with each other! And I wish that we'd both genuinely enjoy it!" The woman giddily blurted out, not considering how vague and open-ended her wish was. She didn't take the time to consider all the ways the wish could possibly drive she and her child. But, so long as she and John were able to spend time with each other, she cared not for what the wish would result in.

For just a fraction of a moment, nothing appeared to have taken place. Jenna was on the edge of tears. She wished, though a response to the wish had yet to have happened. This was the only opportunity she had for genuine mother-son time. Would she be let down? Was this stone only a sort of tease? Jenna thought so.

"No... No... No! This can't ha-!" Jenna cursed to herself, but was suddenly cut off by a strange feeling. What was happening? Was the wish coming into play? Jenna ran into her restroom to look into a mirror.

"What the-?" Jenna gazed in awe at reflection in the mirror. She was shrinking. Physically shrinking! Under normal circumstances, she'd be full of dread. But, she smiled to herself, filled with content in the mystery. Why? For she knew her wish was working it's magic. She didn't know how, but surely she was bound to get what she'd been praying for god only knows how long.

In reply to her shrinking, she just smiled, spoke not a word, uttered not a sound. Just smiled and let the change happen.



She continued shrinking, her frame transitioned to that of a teenage girl, of about 14 years of age. Her hair went from a pale brown, to a light brunette color. On her face, all the signs of age disappeared, leaving behind a youthful, vibrant face of a teen girl. Her arms and legs also lost signs of age and become much more petite, the same for her feet and hands. After which, she shrank in height going form her 5'5" to a youthful 5'1".

For a final touch, her clothes began to change as well. The hum-drum outfit she currently wore, which consisted of jeans, a t-shirt, and sneakers, changed into a strapless maroon colored dress, and, the sneakers had changed into a black pair of ballet flats.

And, so, the change was complete. Jenna Robinson went from a 35 year old woman to a 14 year old teenage girl. At this point all Jenna could help to do was to stare into the mirror at her reflection in satisfaction. She truly was satisfied. She looked exactly like she did when she was John's age. She even wore one of her favorite outfits as a teen. She looked truly amazing, if she did say so herself.

"Wow!" Jenna the teen chirped in her much higher pitched voice. "I even sound like I did at 14! This is great!" Jenna exclaimed happily.

In the midst of all this joy and rejuvenation, a series of thoughts broke it. "What will John think? Will he recognize me? Will he think I'm just some crazy girl? Where is this wish going?" Jenna thought to herself aloud, in a rather anxious tone. Again, Jenna's fit of anxiety was broken by the sound of the door. It was John.

"I'm here!" John called out. Jenna was absolutely fear-struck.

Pushing the fear aside, Jenna went to greet John, wondering how her wish affected him.

"Hi, Honey..." Jenna sheepishly greeted her son walking to the door where John was, in her current teenage-girl form, with her teenage-girl voice.

How does John react?

13211122112211.content:
"Hi, Honey..." Jenna sheepishly greeted her son, John.

"Mom?! Is that you?!?!" John shouted in reply at the top of his lungs, experiencing emotions of all sorts.

"Yes, It's me, your mother, Jenna." She replied to her son in a calming tone.

John heard the calming, motherly voice of the girl who stood before him and immediately knew she was indeed his mother. Though it was incredibly odd, he knew.

John had a sea of questions to ask running through his mind, though, purely out of impulse he asked "How did you get yourself to look like that? Is this a joke?!"

Before him was a young boy, standing at about 4'5" and appearing to be no older than the age of 9. He donned short red hair, hair that matched your own, blue eyes, not like yours, blue jeans and a graphic tee-shirt.

"Hey!... Honey?" You greeted, attempting to imitate a motherly greeting, emulating to the best of your teenage boy ability the style in which your own mother greeted you at that age.

"How was your day?" You nervously asked, kneeling down to his height, trying your best to be motherly, though you did find kneeling a bit awkward considering your skirt and a breeze...

"It was good, Mommy! Today we-" The boy was suddenly cut off by another voice, that of a girl.

"Hi, Mom!" The voice chirped. Startled by the abruptness of the girl's voice, you rapidly got up from your kneeled position and greeted awkwardly "Hiya... Sweetheart?" You spoke.

The girl looked at you a bit awkwardly, noticing that something about her mother, you, seemed... Off. "Sooo..." The girl started, scratching the side of her head, "How're you doing?"

"Uhm... Fine, sweety. Just fine. How about yourself?" You asked, looking around the house curiously as a dog in an unfamiliar setting.

"Ugh... Okay..." She replied, walking away given the awkward air emenating from your presence. The girl looked to be about, you would say, 13 years old and stood at 5'1". Her eyes were blue, unlike your own. She wore a brand name pair of jeans, a pair of flats, and a floral-print blouse, donning that fiery-red hair of yours tied in a pony tail.

You continued exploring the house, despite the awkward encounter with one of your... Daughters. "I thought I had three kids..." You thought to yourself. In the midst of your exploration of this brave new world, a voice shouted...

"Hey, Mom! Nice skirt!" The voice was that of another teenage girl. You looked her way and gave her a quick scan, not wanting to come across as awkward. The girl looked to be a year or two older than your former body, so, about 15 or 16. This girl, unlike 'your,' other two children, possessed light brown hair and green eyes, like yours. She appeared to be about 5'5" tall. She wore a pair of shorts a pink tee-shirt, and wore black and white converse on her feet.

"Hey, Nicole! And, thanks for the compliment!" You chirped. After you said that, you quickly reached for and covered your mouth. You had no idea what her name was, it just came out. That sounded like a genuine mother. Too genuine. You didn't mean to sound like that. Anyway, you 'daughter,' continued.

"No problem! It is a nice skirt, though!" The girl continued.

"Yeah, it is! I got it at the Neiman Marcus in the mall! You remember? You were there!" You again chirped, covering your lips, again. You had no idea where this info was coming from. Now you were terrified.

"Oh, yeah! I remember! Hey, Mom?"

"What is it, Dear?" You again said, without meaning to.


"Would it be cool if a few friends came over tonight?"

"Sure, Honey! Just make sure you guys leave your sister, Sarah, and your brother, Jack, alone!" You now knew the kids' names, but, still, you were terrified inside. "What is happening?!?!" You shouted in your head, still playing it cool on the outside.

"Will do, Mom! Thanks!"

"Honey?" You nervously asked.

"Yeah, Mom?"

"Do you know where your father is?"

"Oh, sure! He..."
1321112212212112122.title: Mom's Home!

choices: Go to your old home and find your Mother.
13211122122121121221.content:
"Oh, sure!" Your 'daughter,' Nicole answered, "He's upstairs, getting ready for your date tonight!"

"Date?!" You asked sharply, the teenage boy in you sweating bullets as you did. Sure, you had gone your share of dates before, but... You had gone in your male body. Never had you attended a date as... The woman!

"Yeah!" Started Nicole, "Your date! Your anniversary date? Y'know, the date couples typically go on to celebrate so many years of marriage? You seriously don't remember?"

As the teenage boy in you anxiously quivered, attempting to come up with a reply, the adult woman in you was awoken and spoke up giddily..

"Oh, yes!" you chirped, "Our anniversary date! Our 20th anniversary! Yes, of course I remember, Darling!" How could you forget? 20 years you had been married to that man you loved oh-so-much, Dave. You remember the day you married him, the dress you wore, the attire he donned, the tears shed by your parents, and the excitement in the eyes of yourself, your husband. How could you forget? Just then, the teenage boy in you regained control. Relief!

"Well, glad you remember, Mom!" Nicole smiled, giving you a hug. "By the way, Dad's looking pretty spiffy!" She winked. "So, I'll be off. Bye, Mom!" She waved, heading out the door.

You took a sigh of relief. "I've got to get to Mom!" You said to yourself. "I'm becoming more and more like this Joanne woman by the second! I've got to get to her! But, I can't just leave this Dave guy, either. I mean... We're married now. And... It is OUR anniversary..." You sighed...

So... What do you do?
13211122122121121221.title: How could you forget?

132111221221211212212.content:
You gave this some serious thought... The door, the way out of all of this was right before you. You'd leave, get in Joanne's car, find your Mom, and become her son again, the person you should and want to be. But, on the other hand, you couldn;t just run away from this life either. You had a life here now! You're a mother of three, your kids seem to like you, you have a loving husband, and there's no mentioning that it is your current body's 20th year of holy matrimony! You knew full well what had to be done.

With that, you took a deep breath in, and a deep breath out as you clicked and clacked your high-heeled feet upstairs to confront Joanne's life.

"The time WILL come for me to change back into John Robinson, teenager and son of Jenna Robinson..." You assured yourself. "But, right now..." You began, placing your hand on the doorknob to the room you assumed belonged to Joanne and Dave, "I'm Joanne Stiles. Mother and... Wife." You said solemnly, turning the knob, opening the door.

You let the door push open slowly, hearing the soft creak of the hinges as it swung lightly. You stood outside the door, peeking inside to make sure no threat lay inside. Bravely, you waltzed into the bedroom unknown to you. Clearly, this Joanne woman lay somewhere in the upper class, or at least upper-middle class. The bedroom held a monstrous super king sized bed, decorated with black pillows and blankets of white and maroon. Two night stands sat by the bed, one on each side. Both had lamps, a drawer or two, but it was clear as to which side was Joanne's, given all the cosmetics sprawled all about it. Across from the bed was a entertainment system, encasing various pictures in respective frames and a medium sized LCD television, underneath the TV was quite the large selection of DVD's, about a quarter of which being home-movies. Right by the nightstand on Joanne's side of the bed was a huge vanity, again, cluttered with make-ups, mirrors, and various products of the like. You decided to walk over to the vanity, as to check yourself out in the mirror, one final time before you're off on this date.

You observed yourself in awe. There were no words in the english vocabulary to describe the way you looked tonight. You're looks were too marvelous for words. Your luscious red hair curled beautifully, reaching a few inches below your shoulders. Your skin was a pastier shade of white, but the pale white skin only complimented the radiant red hair you boasted, the skin also complimented your charming emerald green eyes. Your lips were full in shape and of a pinkish shade of lipstick. Too marvelous for words were your looks.

As you stood there, losing yourself in your new-found beauty, you gave a jump and a yelp of sorts as you heard a masculine voice behind you. Dave.

132111221221212.content:
"Please, Sweetie! Honey, please realize I had no control in this! All I wished for was to spend more time with you! Then this happened!" Jenna begged and pleaded, quite literally on her knees, as well as on the edge of tears. Jenna, for just the slightest of moments, considered how strange this must look from an external point of view. A woman, herself, pleading to another woman, her son in a woman's body, not to leave. How she ended up in this scenario, she'd never know.


John also looked at the ongoing conversation between himself and his mother as odd. "Seriously, this is pretty weird." He said in his mind, in his normal, teenage boy voice. But the voice in his head and the voice of his body didn't match. It doesn't sound like that big a deal, but, from John's point of view, it was down-right weird. He looked down at his mother and felt a mixture of both contempt and pity. Contempt solely because she did deserve the scorn she was receiving. She, whether or not it was any fault of hers, did turn her only son into a woman. Not a girl, a woman. This shaved a good 30 some years off of his natural life. Pity, because John did feel sorry for her. She looked so desperate to spend some quality time with her son. And, as she spoke, the sound in her voice fore-shadowed tears.

John took a step back, away from his mother and found the clicking and clacking of heels that matched perfectly his footsteps to be strange. Anyhow, he stepped away from Jenna and, at that moment, all went silent. His mother anxiously awaited a response of some sort, be it physical or vocal.

John put his hands to his hips, looked up and took a deep sigh. This was something John didn't intend to do. This put fear into John. It seemed that he was taking on womanly mannerisms subconsciously. After his sigh, he looked down to his mom.

"So..." He began in his new feminine voice. "You promise me that you didn't mean to do this?" He finished.

Jenna wasted no time responding. "Of course not, Sweetheart! Had I known this would be the result, I would've never even thought of it!"

"So, please..." She continued. "Spend a day with your mother. When the day is done, or tomorrow, you can turn me into whatever you want! I promise!" Jenna pleaded.

"Hmm..." Sighed John, tapping his right foot as he thought about it, another mannerism not his own.

The clicking of his heel as he tapped reminded him, he had not yet looked at his body, he only heard it's voice. He looked down to himself.

Mid-length red hair that reached only a little beyond the shoulders decorated his head. His weight looked to be perfect. Not too skinny and not too fat. However, the fat that was present rested on his rear and breasts. Though John couldn't see it, his lashes were very finely done and his were shaded a certain shade of forest green. Pale white skin, though not too pale, covered his body, and made his legs look down-right amazing. He was wearing a skirt, sheer blouse, and blazer while a simple pair of black heels decorated his now dainty feet. Had one not known any better, one may have mistaken him for a spitting image of Christina Hendricks.

"Well..." He finally uttered.

"Yes, Dear!" Jenna, full of hope, answered.

"You did make me look... Pretty awesome." Jenna smiled. "So... Sure. I'll spend some time with you." He said forgivingly.

"Yay!" Cheered Jenna, who jumped and gave John a warm motherly embrace, despite the fact that her son was now the same age, and gender, as her.

"So... What exactly do we do now?" John inquired.

"Well, I don't know. It's your call." Jenna replied.

"Uhm... How about we..."

The morning dew that rested on the grass, and all about the environment, reflected the brilliant shine of the A.M. sun. Birds whistled, the sound of the occasional car passing by could be heard. All and all, a beautiful morning was just waiting anxiously to be had.

All the while, 12 year old Samuel 'Sam' Woods, stared at the morning scenery in an innocent, child-like awe and wonder.

"Wow! This HAS to be what life is all about! Awesome mornings like this!" Sam proudly said to himself, making himself comfy on the seat behind him, placing his feet onto the small coffee table his mother kept on the porch. believing himself to have discovered the meaning of life.

Sam sighed a contented sigh, pushed his light-weight backpack aside, laid back in his chair, and scanned the scenery once more. The grass had it's shine, the trees beautifully held the dew as well. It truly was a sparkling morning. Everything about had that dewy glow. As Sam continued his scan, something got his attention. This was rare, especially considering his attention span was no higher than his age.

"Whoa! What's that!" Sam exclaimed. "It's like a star or something!" Sam did a double-take about him, as to make sure his mother or sister weren't watching. If they were, surely they'd pester him for something stupid as they always did.

When Sam was sure his family was not around, he dashed for the mysterious object in his yard that shone like a star.

Sam, in his excitement wasted no time in dashing for the object and making a grab for it. With a wide smile on his face, he reached for it and beheld...

"A rock?!" He shouted, clearly disappointed. But, yes, what Sam held in his small hands was a white rock that shone furiously. "It's just a stupid rock... But... It is a pretty stupid rock." He justified, falling in love with the rock once again. Sam couldn't explain it, the rock just had a magnetic aura about it. An aura that attracted you to it no matter what.

"I know! I'll give it to Mom! She wears rocks all the time!" Sam said, referring to her single necklace.

The front door to the Woods' home violently slammed open, immediately capturing the attention of its other two occupants, the matriarch, Nicole and her daughter, Sam's older sister, Victoria.

"You little twerp!" 17 year-old Victoria furiously shouted. "What was that all about! As if I didn't get enough sleep already!" This quickly halted Sam's excitement. He hated it when his sister yelled at him like that.

"Victoria! Don't you speak to your little brother like that!" 38 year-old Nicole jumped in, defending her son. Sam's excitement, just as quickly as it faded, returned with his mother's presence.

"What?! You heard how loud that was!" Victoria defended herself.

The room fell silent. Nicole had no argument to deliver. Victoria smiled at her victory. "That was really, really loud, Sam. What was it all about?" Nicole, in the sweetest of voices asked Sam, who didn't hesitate in answering.

"I found a rock!" Sam shouted.

"That's soooo fascinating! Please, tell us more about it!" Victoria sarcastically urged, triggering a sour look of disapproval from her mother.

Sam, however, failed to recognize the sarcasm and continued.

"Yeah, I found this rock!" Sam exclaimed, pulling out the still-glimmering stone from his jean pockets. The moment, he exposed the wondrous rock, the eyes of his mom and sister began to glow in the strangest sense of awe. Sam, thought nothing of it, and proceeded.

"I found it in the yard out-front. It really caught my eye! It looked like a star!"

"It sure does, Bro..." Victoria agreed, still under the stones spell.

Nicole began to think to herself... "Wow! Look at that thing! It's amazing! Beautiful! I have to have it... Come on, Nicole, work your motherly magic..."

"Sam, Honey?"

"Yeah, Mom?" Replied Sam.

"Would you mind showing me the stone?"

"Sure! All ya have to do is ask!" Sam complied, failing to fall victim to the stones charm.

"Thank you, Dear!" Nicole warmly said, providing her son a hug.

"Can I see it when you're done, Mom?" Victoria asked, the anxiousness present in her voice.

"Sure! When I'm done..." Nicole said.

A few awkward moments passed that consisted of nothing but Victoria literally on the edge of her seat, waiting for her mother to become finished with the stone, Nicole just staring at the stone with a particular sense of wonder, and Sam, well, he just waited patiently...

"Alright, Mom!" Victoria snapped. "I think you're time is up! It's my turn to see that thing!"

Nicole stepped back a little, a tad frightened by the passion Victoria was currently full of over that stone.

"..." Nicole stood silent, defending the stone.

"Hey!" Sam shouted. "You can't let her have it! You saw how she yelled at me! And you, just now! You should hand the rock to me!"

"What do you mean 'her?'" Victoria, clearly offended, asked her brother.

As the two began to bicker and fight, Nicole felt incredibly pressured. All this chaos over a rock. A rock! A very lovely rock, though... A rock this pretty couldn't be just any ordinary rock though. It just had to be capable of something. Nicole had see way too many "Indiana Jones" movies for a stone such as this not to dosomething. Nicole had to decide. Now.

What to do, what to do...

choices: Fine. He's also a young professional, and understands Lily's plight.
Not well. Erik is at the end of his rope with Lily and her job.
1322211.content:
Our protagonist's name is Lily Gordon. Lily is a young, new attorney at a mid-sized law firm in a large city. She comes from money, her father being the heir to her grandfather's shipping empire. Lily has never wanted for anything in life, and is now attempting to make her own way as an attorney. She is decently paid, but nowhere near commensurate with the workload she shoulders as she attempts to scratch and claw her way up the corporate ladder. By anyone's interpretation, Lily is an attractive girl, albeit rather average. Nothing about Lily's appearance particularly stands out, and that suits Lily fine because she has never much cared what others thought when they looked at her. She was more concerned with how they would perceive her as an attorney, and as an adversary in the courtroom.

For an idea, here's Lily's latest professional photo, which is loaded onto her profile on the firm's website:

http://bit.ly/1UuwJvc

Lately, Lily has been doing much of her work for a senior associate, Jack Hanover, who is more often playing games on his phone or setting up tee times, which leaves Lily with a much larger burden than a typical junior associate. One Friday around 5, as Lily was organizing her desk and packing her things for the weekend, Jack ambled into her office and asked, "Got a minute?" Lily's heart sank. There went her Friday night plans before Jack even opened his mouth.

"I need you to work up a memo on the Franklin case before you leave this evening. Also, I have a deposition on Monday. I need it prepared by Sunday morning, so I can have time to review it. Oh, and I have some clients that have been hounding me for status updates. Could you be a doll and shoot some emails over the weekend to keep them at bay?"

Inside Lily was seething. Jack was only a few years her senior, and yet he treated her like a fucking intern. Despite her inner rage, Lily plastered on a fake smile, and through gritted teeth, calmly replied, "Of course Jack. Have a good weekend." And with that, Jack gave a quick smile and fled to his happy hour du jour. Lily hated this part of her job, but she knew that it would all pay off. She was scheduled to have a performance review next week where she would learn if she would make senior associate next month. That would mean a major jump in pay, as well as a way to get out from under Jack's thumb. It was only a few more weeks of this torture, and Lily would be free.

As she settled back in for what was sure to be a long evening, another visitor greeted Lily. This time it was Vanessa Rodriguez, Jack's assistant. Vanessa was headed out herself, as she was a lowly 9-5 employee, but she needed to pop in to provide Lily with some more details as to exactly what Jack was demanding she do over the weekend. These Friday afternoon "meetings" had become commonplace, and as a result, Lily and Vanessa shared an odd sort of kinship.

"He has you here late again?" Vanessa said, with more than a touch of sympathy in her voice.

"You're surprised? This is what, four, no wait, FIVE weeks in a row?"

Vanessa rolled her eyes and muttered something about Jack under her breath in Spanish. Lily knew that Jack was quite the lecherous type, as she watched him gawk and stare at Vanessa on more than one occasion. Although, to be fair, Jack wasn't the only person at the office who stopped to stare at Vanessa. Whereas Lily was rather average and plain, Vanessa was anything but. While Lily was thin and narrow, like a flat open road, Vanessa was curvy like a winding mountain pass. Even though Vanessa was shorter than Lily by a good measure, her womanly attributes were far more exaggerated. Vanessa's prodigious ass was the topic of more than a few water cooler conversations among the other members of the office. Men lusted over her physique, while women snickered at her objectification. All of this meant nothing to Vanessa, who reveled in the attention. To be perfectly frank, she loved it. Vanessa was more than a bit of a slut.

Even though she was only 22, Vanessa already had two children, a five year old, and a two year old. Being a mother, however, did nothing to stop Vanessa from dressing up to show off her best attributes. She had joined the firm with hopes of finding a rich attorney to take care of her and her brood. Vanessa frequently pushed the bounds of acceptable office attire, wearing the shortest dresses and tightest skirts to emphasize her "moneymaker." While not classically beautiful, Vanessa exuded a raw sexuality which more than made up for it.

For better reference, here's Vanessa latest office selfie taken earlier that morning:

http://bit.ly/1MvGGk9

Despite sympathizing with Lily, Vanessa didn't want to linger. It was a Friday after all. She quickly relayed the pertinent information, and tottered out of Lily's office on her sky high stilettos. Lily swore she even caught the bottom of one of Vanessa's round, plump ass cheeks as she flitted away. "What it must be like to be that carefree..." Lily thought idly to herself. She promptly dismissed such thoughts, however, and returned back to her work. If she wanted to get out of here by midnight, there was no time for daydreaming.

Later that night, Lily finally wrapped up the memo, and headed home. She arrived at her apartment around 11, which was early compared to prior weeks. She noticed numerous missed texts from her boyfriend, Erik. She called him and recounted her evening with him, reflecting on how unfair it all was. Erik was understanding, but his patience was waning these past few months. Having Lily as a girlfriend was great, but it was less enjoyable when she was never able or willing to do anything on weekends aside from lounge around their apartments working or watching Netflix. Erik again asked if she wanted to meet up for a drink with a few friends, but Lily declined. She was truly exhausted, and instead opted for a long shower, about three pages of a book she'd been reading for years, and the warm embrace of her bed.

The same story played itself out on Saturday. Lily was buried in Jack's work, and again declined an invitation to go out with her boyfriend. How does Erik take this second rejection?
1322211.title: Male

choices: Great. Lily was promoted to senior associate, and received a six figure salary.
Horrible. Lily was passed over and remained a lowly junior associate.
13222112.content:
"Are you fucking kidding, Lil? Again. It's a Saturday..." Erik said, incredulously.

"I know, babe. I'm sorry. I have my review this week, and if all goes well, I'll be a senior next month and Jack can go fuck himself."

"No. This isn't going to end. Do you really think when you become a senior you're going to have less work, and less responsibility? Jack gets away with it because he could care less. I know you. You would never be so lazy. The only difference is you'll be doing your own work all weekend." Erik sighed, "Look, Lil, I love and respect you. I couldn't be prouder of your career, but its not a one-way street. You need to prioritize me sometimes, and I can see that will never happen. Maybe sometime in the future you'll understand and we can be together, but right now, this just isn't working."

Lily began tearing, and through sniffles, said "You're breaking up with me?? But Erik, I love you..."

"And I love you babe. But this isn't working for either of us. I feel like I'm constantly pestering you, and to me, you're a ghost. We just need some space."

Lily was flabbergasted, and rendered speechless. She didn't know what to say, so she just hung up and began sobbing. She spent the rest of Saturday alone in her bed going through every stage of grief and loss she knew. While her friends were supportive, none of it made up for the fact that Erik was gone, and it was her career that killed them. Lily wasn't even allowed the whole weekend to recover, however, as she had to spend all day Sunday making up for the time she lost Saturday.

When she arrived at the office Monday morning, Lily looked and felt like a zombie. She was back with her nose to the grindstone as she heard Vanessa around the cubicles chatting with the other assistants about how fun their weekends were. In lapses in concentration, Lily heard tales of nightclubs, VIP sections, bottles of champagne, cute guys, and generally fun times. While Lily couldn't help but feel a twinge of jealousy, she quelled those thoughts as she knew that she would soon receive her promotion, and all of this toil would prove to be worth it. Those $35k per year hens can keep squawking about how wonderful their henhouse is, but Lily had her eye on the penthouse.

Later that afternoon, Lily received a call from the managing partner of her division, summoning her to his office for her annual performance review. Lily strode past Vanessa and the other assistants, ready to receive her just reward.

How did Lily's review go?
13222112.title: Not well. Erik is at the end of his rope with L...

choices: Vanessa was just as shocked as Lily.
Vanessa thought everything was perfectly normal.
132221122.content:
Lily slammed the door to her windowless office and fell back into her chair as the tears returned. While the partner had praised her for her work and work ethic, she got the lecture about the firm tightening its belt, cutting back on senior associates, and offering her a perfunctory raise of a couple thousand dollars. Lily was floored. Not only did she lose out on the promotion and raise, she was now stuck for another year being Jack's lackey.

Lily had always shunned the notion that being a woman would have placed limits on how far she could rise in the world. Her father had been rather modern in his view, encouraging her to pursue her dreams and never be discouraged. She could do anything a man could do if she put her mind to it. Now, however, those thoughts seemed distant and rung hollow for her. As she sat and slaved over her work for 80 hours a week she watched the other women in the office mincing about and mindlessly gabbing about fashion, hair, and men. Those same women, however, made roughly 75% as much money as she did. It just wasn't fair. It wasn't worth it.

As Lily slipped deeper into self-pity, there was a knock on her door, as the young intern Robbie was waiting with her mail. Included among various notices and filings, however, was a small brown box with no postage label, just her name and address written haphazardly in sharpie. After Robbie closed the door, Lily curiously opened the box. Inside was a plain black stone, slick and smooth like one you would find in a river bed. On top of the stone, however, was a post-it note which read "Rub for Wishes."

Lily scrunched her face in confusion and anger. She assumed someone, maybe Jack, was playing a sick trick on her after her negative review. But that would seem unlikely. No one so much as had an opinion about Lily. She was like the human equivalent of wallpaper. She was there, and no one really cared. Trying not to think of it, Lily casually slipped the stone in her purse and began counting the minutes until she could head home.

That night at her apartment, Lily's emptiness and loneliness became all the more acute. Erik was gone. Her friends were tired of constantly comforting her. She was staring down the barrel of yet another horrible year. Lily could think of nothing else to do but pop the cork on a rather large bottle of cheap red wine she had purchased for a party which she never attended. Lily's sadness welled up inside her and quickly released itself in the form of a literal shower of tears. For hours, Lily sat in silence at her kitchen table going over her unhappiness in her head as she absentmindedly drank glass after glass of wine.

It didn't take long before Lily was three sheets to the wind. Her tears and thoughts became more blubbery and nonsensical as the bottle slowly emptied. In a moment of clarity, Lily thought of Vanessa and what she must have been doing right then. Gone were the earlier feelings of superiority. In their place, Lily felt pangs of jealousy. She flipped through Vanessa's various social media accounts, all the while drinking in the fun, carefree life she portrayed online. After a good twenty minutes of perusing, Lily thought of the wishing stone. She let out a drunken chuckle, thinking of how dumb she was for even considering what she was considering. But at this point, Lily's ability to analyze and reflect had been reduced to thinking "fuck it, who cares?"

So on a lark, Lily grabbed the stone from her purse, gave it a quick rub, and said aloud, "I wish my job were easy like Vanessa's." Immediately, there was a brief flash of light, but nothing happened. Lily was still drunk. She was still sitting in her kitchen chair. Nothing had changed. She was just as miserable as before.

"Well of course," she thought to herself. "What did you expect?"

Dejected, Lily stood up and staggered to her bed, where she flopped down in her work clothes and promptly fell asleep.

The next morning, Lily awoke with a splitting headache. She cursed herself for being so stupid to get that drunk on a Monday. She was running late and hastily got dressed and schlepped off to work. She slumped into her chair and flipped on her monitor to pick up where she had left off the day before. Before she could even open her email, Jack popped his head in and snapped, "Lily, what do you think you're doing in Vanessa's office? Can't you hear my phone ringing?"

"Vanessa's office?" Lily thought to herself. "What is he talking about?"

But her brain was fuzzy, she was hungover, and she was confident Jack had misspoke. Nevertheless, Vanessa wasn't at the office yet, and her boss was telling her to answer the phone, so Lily hopped up, ran over to Vanessa's desk, grabbed the phone and said, breathlessly, "Jack Hanover's office." The voice on the other end of the line was bubbly and friendly, and shocked Lily when she greeted her by her own name. "Hey Lily, this is Kaylee from Regional Health Services, returning your call about the records for Mr. Franklin that you had requested. I have them here, and am going to send them over, but I misplaced your fax number. Could you give it to me again?"

Lily, on autopilot, mumbled back the firm's fax number, to which Kaylee gave a chipper "Thanks! Talk to you later. Bye!"

Lily sat back in Vanessa's chair, numb from shock. "Who was that, and how did she know my name?" Just then, Lily remembered last night, the wine, and the stone.

"It couldn't be," she thought. Lily reached forward with a trembling hand, grabbed the nameplate on Vanessa's desk, and turned it around to read "Lily Gordon" where "Vanessa Rodriguez" should have been. Lily whipped around and looked back at her door, to see Vanessa's name now on the nameplate. Stunned, Lily was speechless as Vanessa strolled through the lobby. She didn't look any different to Lily, but how did the stone affect Vanessa?
132221122.title: Horrible. Lily was passed over and remained a l...

choices: "No, I don't want to risk using the stone again. Who knows what will happen?"
"Well, I guess it couldn't hurt. Do you have any ideas?
1322211221.content:
Vanessa walked over to Lily's new desk with a confused look on her face. "Hey girl," she said, "what's up? Sorry I'm late. Did Jack make you answer the phone again?"

Lily turned to her, grabbed her by the arm, and hauled her into what had been Lily's office. "Vanessa, I have no clue how this happened, but somehow you and I switched jobs. I came in this morning, and my name was on your desk, and your's was on my office."

Vanessa smiled and laughed. "OK, sure. Good one. You're quite the kidder. I'm going to get back to work now."

"No I'm serious," Lily insisted. "I just got a call from Kaylee at Regional, and she greeted me by name. Also, that nameplate is carved glass. Who was going to fake that just to play a prank on you??"

Vanessa's eyes narrowed as she tried to think of how Lily was getting one over on her. "But what caused all this?" she asked.

With a sigh, Lily launched into a full explanation of the stone, and how it was mailed to her, how she got drunk alone last night, and how she had finally wished that her job had been easy like Vanessa's.

"So, as far as I can tell, the stone interpreted that wish as me asking to swap jobs with you. Now it seems as though you're an attorney and I'm Jack's assistant."

"But I don't have any clue how to be an attorney," Vanessa replied.

"And I have no clue how to be a good assistant, but we've got to get through this together. We'll just email each other throughout the day and walk the other through what to do. I think I can handle the phone, and I can do most of my legal work from your computer anyways. We just have to make it to the end of the day, and then we'll figure this all out."

"I suppose," Vanessa said. "I'll do my best, I promise."

With that, Lily left Vanessa in what had been her office, and trudged back to her "new" desk. She sat down in the smaller, less comfortable chair the firm provided assistants, and went about the process of attempting to orient herself. It was odd to be placed in the middle of the office without a door for privacy. People were constantly walking past her and greeting her, which was exceptionally odd because no one else seemed to think that Lily was out of place at all. Lily, however, felt as though she stuck out like a sore thumb. She was dressed in her usual blazer and looked like an attorney sitting at her little assistant's desk.

Lily, however, simply focused on getting through the day. She ended up being exceptionally busy, having to do her usual work as well as answer the phone. Luckily, Jack was in depositions all week, and would be out of the office, which afforded Lily the opportunity to get work done outside the watchful eye of her boss. It was unusual, however, to have to email completed memos to Vanessa so that she could turn around and send them to Jack. It would've been unusual for a lowly assistant to draft such a memo, after all.

After what seemed like an eternity, five o'clock rolled around and Vanessa and Lily bolted for the door. They agreed to go back to Lily's apartment so they could sort everything out, because that's where the stone was. When they arrived, they sat at Lily's table and figured that the best course of action would be to just wish to swap jobs again. So Lily grabbed the stone, rubbed it, and wished aloud, "I wish that I could have my old job back, and Vanessa could have her's."

They sat in silence for a moment as nothing happened.

"Is that it?" Vanessa asked. "Did it work?"

"I don't think so," said Lily. "Last time there was this big flash of light." She paused for a moment, thinking, before continuing, "let's check our emails. If you still have memo assignments from Jack then we haven't switched back."

Vanessa whipped out her phone and sure enough, there was a new memo from Jack asking her to research a particularly nuanced issue of law.

"Shit," muttered Lily. The two girls sat and racked their brains for a few more hours, trying to figure out how to solve their dilemma, all to no avail. It quickly got late, and the girls became discouraged.

"I guess we'll just have to try figuring this out tomorrow." Lily said.

"Do you think there's anything we can do to help us out? I know it must have been tough for you, basically doing everything. Maybe we can make a wish that can help share the work between us?" Vanessa asked.

Lily thought about it, and then replied...
1322211221.title: Vanessa was just as shocked as Lily.

choices: She had found an article that she thought might be what they were looking for.
13222112212.content:
Vanessa thought about it for a moment, and then said, "Why don't we wish to know how to do the other's job? That way, we can each do our "new" jobs while we figure this out, and when we swap back, we won't end up way behind."

"Seems like a good idea. It does seem a bit odd to be doing so much legal research when I'm technically just an assistant. We can still help each other out, but it will be good to have some knowledge of my own."

With the plan hatched, Lily picked up the stone and rubbed it as she had before. She then said aloud, "I wish we each had the necessary knowledge to fully perform our 'new' jobs." Just as it had last night, there was a blinding flash of light, and the two women looked at each other in shock.

"Do you feel any different?" Vanessa asked quickly.

"No," Lily replied. "It's the same as last night. I think the swap happened while I slept."

The pair spent a few more minutes going over their plans for the next day. Vanessa would handle Lily's work, and Lily would spend most of her time trying to research the stone to see if she could dig up anything on how it worked, to see if they could have a better idea of how to get back to normal. Once they had settled on their plan, Vanessa went home, and Lily went to bed. As Lily lay in bed, her mind was racing a mile a minute thinking of all the problems they were facing, and whether or not she would ever solve the mystery of the stone. This would have usually kept Lily up all night, however, a powerful force seemingly thrust Lily into a deep sleep. Seemingly, the magic needed time to work.

Lily awoke to her alarm the next morning, and just as she had Tuesday morning, felt rather hungover. This was odd, however, because Lily hadn't drank anything the night before. But the feeling was distinct and familiar. She felt groggy and slow, as if the synapses in her brain weren't firing on all cylinders that morning. Lily plodded into the bathroom and went about the process of getting ready for work. She again selected a black suit, as she had the day before, with sensible two inch heels. As she got dressed, the grogginess faded, but that feeling of slowness lingered. Lily couldn't shake the sense that she was somehow "off" that morning.

Her first hint that something had changed occurred as she was eating breakfast. Her phone buzzed with an email from Jack, informing her that something had come up in his deposition, and that he needed new medical records for a client, and he needed them by tomorrow. As an attorney, Lily never dealt with actually obtaining records. She used them frequently when she drafted motions and briefs, but she never had to call the hospitals and doctor's offices to order them. That was a job left to the assistants and support staff, which Lily was now seemingly a member of.

Despite having no experience, when Lily read the email her mind was flooded with the step by step analysis of what she had to do to get the records. Lily knew that a single day turnaround was a highly unusual request, but she scanned the email, say which hospital it was, and knew exactly the person she had to call. If she just called Aimee at St. Mary's she could probably convince her to get the records over today. She could just gossip about Aimee's beau, and once she got her feeling all chummy, she would do whatever Lily needed.

In the middle of her thought, Lily suddenly stopped. All these thoughts were totally foreign, yet they seemed so natural. It must have been the stone's work. It seemed as though Lily now knew exactly what she needed to do to be Jack's assistant. Lily couldn't help but chuckle to herself. It was so bizarre to have someone else's knowledge, and even though it was happening under such unfortunate circumstances, it was still objectively odd and funny.

At work, Lily noticed that Vanessa was already at her computer, seemingly engrossed in an assignment. Lily decided to leave her be and talk later. She had to deal with those records anyways. Lily sat at her desk, and for the next few hours, she worked the phones trying to get a hold of the records Jack needed. While Lily knew exactly what to do, that sense of slowness from that morning still hadn't left her. While she was able to get everything done, she just found that it took her longer, and she was easily distracted. Like when a pair of assistants was gossiping over by the copier, Lily couldn't help but listen in, even though she really didn't care what they were gabbing about.

Despite the slowness, Lily was still able to convince Aimee to spend the afternoon amassing the records, and having them sent over to Lily's office that evening by courier. Feeling accomplished, Lily popped into her old office to check on Vanessa.

"How's it going?" She asked, curiously.

"Great," Vanessa said. "I can't even begin to describe how empowered and quick I feel. It's like a million fireworks are going off in my brain non-stop. I have all this new knowledge, and yeah, the work is hard, but I'm convinced that I can tackle any assignment. Could you just look over this motion really quick, and make sure everything is right? I think it is, but hey, it's my first day, I want to make sure."

Lily took the papers from Vanessa and began skimming them. The motion was a simple and routine one, or at least that's what Lily thought. She vaguely remembered doing motions like this, although the memories felt very detached and distant, as if she herself hadn't done it. As Lily pored over the pages, she quickly realized that it felt like she was reading Greek. She couldn't make heads or tails of anything. Everything seemed like legal jargon, and while she knew what the literal words on the page meant, their legal context was fully lost on her.

"So...." Vanessa inquired, "all good?"

"Umm, to be honest, I don't know." Lily demurred.

"You don't know? But Lily, I know you've done a million of these motions. The facts are all there, I just want you to make sure it's worded and organized correctly."

"I'm serious, though. I have no clue what this even is." The two looked at each other with a mixture of fear and confusion. Lily wracked her brain, trying to recall her years of legal education. Lily tried thinking back to law school, but she couldn't pull any of those memories. It was like she was trying to grasp the mist. The more she thought about it, the more the memories faded. Instead, she could recall dropping out of high school at 17. She remembered that around that time Vanessa had gotten pregnant with her first child. She also remembered going to night school to take courses on being a legal assistant. But she could recall nothing of her own educational experience.

"Tell me anything you learned at your night school courses to become an assistant," Lily asked Vanessa.

"How'd you know about those?" Vanessa asked, surprised. After a brief pause, she continued, "well, they taught us everything we needed to know. To be honest, I can't recall anything specific off the top of my head..."

"Exactly!" Lily interrupted. "I can't remember anything about my law school years either. Somehow, instead of just giving us the knowledge we needed, it swapped all of our education and knowledge!"

"Do you think that's why I've been feeling so sharp and quick all day?" asked Vanessa.

"What do you mean?" Lily replied.

"Well, if it swapped all of our education and knowledge, maybe this is just what it feels like to be smart. I've always known that you were very smart Lily, one of the brightest people in the firm. Maybe this is just what it's like to be you. Do you feel any different?"

"Ummm, yeah, I guess. My mind has felt fuzzy all morning."

"That's how I always felt! It was as if I knew what to do, but there was just some sort of gap sometimes that slowed me down. I guess it took me experiencing being so smart to realize how dumb I really was."

"Hey!" Lily shot back.

"No offense," Vanessa replied earnestly. "I wasn't a moron, I was just a little spacey. My family used to say I was ditzy. I suppose I was also rather gullible. You have to understand, in my family, no one was impressed by an intelligent woman. Your focus was supposed to be on the home and making a family. Because of that, I just never really cared about school. I dropped out of high school because I thought that Juan and I were going to last forever. Obviously, that was a fucking fantasy. I never went back until recently, when I got my GED and took those legal assistant classes."

Lily was stunned, and she took a moment to process the fact that she was now a certifiable ditz. Despite her best efforts, Lily had found nothing concrete about the stone online. "There's just a bunch of old wives' tales and other nonsense. Nothing that seemed legit," Lily said. The girls agreed that they were exhausted after staying up late the night before, and that they would each keep researching on their own.

Lily went home and flipped on her laptop with the expectation of figuring the stone out and swapping back to her old job. She sat down on her couch and picked up her research where she had left off from work. After about fifteen minutes, however, Lily began to lose focus. She saw some ads for various clothing and makeup chains, and quickly found herself absentmindedly skimming through their offers. Lily had never really been one to "surf" the web, instead using it in a more focused manner, however, she was now aimlessly clicking through various outfits and seasonal makeup colors that she thought were "cute" or "fun."

Lily also turned on her often unused TV, and tuned into some mindless "Real Housewives" reality show. She quickly found herself becoming engrossed in the cliched scenarios and contrived inter-personal drama between the women. The old Lily would have never given a show like that even five minutes of her time, but now Lily was enraptured, literally sitting on the edge of her seat. It wasn't until the final credits rolled around ten o'clock that Lily even realized what she had been doing.

"Ughh, what was I thinking. Focus, Lily, focus," she internally chided herself. Lily figured she must just be tired, and vowed to turn in early that evening. As she lay in her bed, she was oddly at ease. Her mind, which was usually racing with thoughts about the next day and what she would have to do, was oddly silent. Instead, she idly thought of the stone, clothes, and TV as she drifted off to sleep.

When she awoke on Thursday morning, Lily felt well rested. She still felt slow, like she had the previous morning, but such feelings were not new anymore, and in a way, Lily was oddly comfortable with not being constantly on edge. That morning she peacefully made breakfast, showered, and took her time getting ready. While she was still rather average in her appearance, Lily knew she looked better than she had in a long time. She also chose to eschew the blazer in favor of a white oxford and her suit pants. "Why would an assistant need a jacket?" she thought.

Lily was also unusually calm that morning at work. She went through her morning routine seemingly on autopilot, responding to emails, calling on records, preparing documents for filing, all without a second thought. She wasn't concerned about impending deadlines, or whether or not Jack would be impressed with her work. For the first time in a long time, Lily also left the office for lunch. She had made a habit of eating one of the granola bars in her desk while she was furiously working, but that had been when she was an attorney. Now, Lily was able to make the full use of her lunch hour, strolling around the sun-drenched city streets, eventually settling on a small cafe with a nice salad, which she ate at a table outside facing a park. Lily returned to her desk feeling reinvigorated and refreshed. "What a treat a real lunch is," she thought to herself. "I really should do that more often."

Lily spent the rest of her afternoon answering the phone, responding to an occasional email, and reacquainting herself with her oft-neglected social media profiles. Lily enjoyed checking up on old friends, and she was surprised to see how many of them had children and were building families. Lily knew she wanted kids eventually, but as an attorney, she had never had the time to really think about it. She wasn't afforded any time to think about it that day either, because it was around that time that Lily's phone rang. It was Vanessa, telling her to meet her in Lily's old office.

"Any update?" Vanessa asked.

"About what?" Lily replied dumbly.

"Lily, the stone. Did you find anything else about the stone?"

"Ohhh, uh no. Same as yesterday," Lily lied, realizing that she had totally forgot to research the thing that had changed her life so dramatically.

"Well, I'm telling you, this whole thing is not easy. I could hardly sleep last night, I'm so bogged down in work." Vanessa started. "I mean, there's only so much that one person can do, you know? I'm just dying on the vine here. I've just wrapped up the brief for the Garrison case, but now I have two or three motions that I need to get out today, and it's already four. Plus, I just had a meeting at two, and I felt absolutely absurd."

"Why?" Lily asked. "You're so smart, though."

"It's not that," Vanessa sighed. "It's that I don't have any outfits suitable for a woman of my position. I felt ridiculous this morning, flipping through my closet. It's all bright dresses and heels. There's not a single suit, or even some button-downs and slacks. I've never been ashamed of my body, I've always enjoyed being so... lush. The thing is, it's one thing to have curves like these, it's another to be flaunting them like I'm some sort of bimbo at a nightclub."

"But I think you look cute," Lily interjected.

"That's sweet of you to say, and I don't disagree. I just feel ridiculous dressed like such a slut in front of other attorneys. They were all staring at me, and some were even snickering. Plus, I don't have the money to go buy a completely new wardrobe. I just feel like this is something we should use the stone for, if only until we can actually figure out how to reverse all this."

"Are you sure that's a good idea?" Lily asked. "Every time we use the stone, it seems to go further than we want."

"Well, I think we understand how the thing works. I don't see how it will mess anything up worse. I mean, we'll just wish for proper clothes, and odds are it'll just swap our wardrobes. Either way, I don't think we have much of a choice. I don't know how many days I can get by. I've got on my most conservative dress, and you can still see my breasts through it."

“Quick question before we go. Why not just wish for new clothes, or to make your old clothes fit?” Bridget asked as she grabbed her hoodie off the ground.

“I’ve been meaning to get some new clothes for work and this is a perfect excuse to go. Besides, I already told you I wasn’t going to abuse the stone,” Sarah responded as she collected her purse.

Bridget rolled her eyes as the two newly buxom woman left the apartment and headed toward the stairs. “The least you can do is wish for an elevator for this place. Walking up and down four flights of stairs every day is annoying.”

“I thought you said you liked the stairs because it meant you didn’t have to make time to go jogging,” Sarah ribbed.

“Great, then you should have no trouble making the trip,” the redhead snarked.

“Your next wish should be to pull the stick out of your ass.”

After descending the stairs the two began walking toward the parking garage. Sarah and Bridget lived in a fairly nice apartment complex that shared a garage with two others that were in the near vicinity. It was one of the few luxuries she allowed herself as it helped in her morning routine to not have to climb multiple flights just to get to work. “What?” Sarah groaned.

“It’s just... You make more than enough money to buy really nice stuff and yet you choose to drive this,” Bridget said as she gestured to the car. It was a dark blue, 2014 subcompact Honda Fit.

“It’s a nice car,” Sarah defended.

“But that’s not why you bought it. You bought it because it was affordable and had good gas mileage.”

“Oh, sorry that I make responsible choices. Would you have rathered I buy a monster truck with flaming tailpipes and a giant skull on the hood.”

“I’m not saying you need to go that far, but a little extravagance never hurt anyone,” Bridget said as she raised the stone in her hand. Sarah gasped as she looked at her pocket that once held the stone.

“How did you even...” Sarah didn’t get to finish her question before Bridget made a wish.

“I wish that Sarah drove a Porsche 918 Spyder,” the mischievous minx proclaimed.

As if it had been there all along, the very car Bridget described was standing before them. It was the same color as Sarah’s old car but that was were the comparison disappeared. Dumbstruck, Sarah stared at the engineering masterpiece as Bridget walked passed her while saying “you’re welcome.”

With swift action, the pragmatic girl took the stone out of Bridget unexpecting hand and shouted “I wish that my car was back to normal.” However, this wish did nothing. “What...”

“Oh well. Looks like you’ll have to just accept that this is your car now and have some fun,” Bridget shrugged with a smile.

“Why didn’t that work?” Sarah asked worried.

“Maybe you can’t unwish something,” Bridget concluded.

“That means we have to be more careful with our wishes. That’s why I didn’t want to just run wild with it. Dammit Bridget, our wishes could have unforeseen consequences. We could really make a big mess out of things,” Sarah said as she brought her hands to the sides of her face as she often did when she was worried.

“Look Sarah, you need to relax. All I’ve done it upgrade your ride. If it makes you feel better I won’t make anymore wishes for the rest of the trip,” she offered.

With a few deep breaths and a sigh, Sarah nodded and pulles her keys out of her purse.

“Oh my god, you are going to have so much fun driving this thing. Dibs on driving home,” Bridget clapped excitedly.

“At least you’re willing to drive now, instead of forcing me to take you everywhere.”

“See. Look at the positives. Now let’s go and see what this baby can do!”

Sarah was understandably cautious as she got in the car. Unlike Bridget, she didn’t much care about cars but she knew how expensive this one was and did her best to treat it with absolute care. She thought she’d have trouble figuring out how the car worked, but she turned it on and pulled out of the spot like she’d driven it for years. Sarah checked all of her mirrors to find they were all perfectly alined with her sight. This intrigued her. She thought back to Bridgets wish. The stone didn’t just turn her car into a porsche. It warped reality so that she had always driven one. It both terrified and fascinated Sarah, but now she had to focus on driving. She did make a mental note to talk to Bridget about this discovery when they got back, but for now they had clothes to buy.

Elaine Wilson wearily unlocked the door to her apartment. The 32 year old woman entered the living room, put down her briefcase and collapsed on the couch. It was the worst ... correction, second worst day of her life. She had officially lost her job. It was not entirely unexpected; rumors of layoffs at the company had been brewing for months.

Elaine lied on the couch for about half an hour before getting up and went to the telephone. She promised to tell her mother what happened. She dialed the number, and after a few rings a familiar voice asked, “Hello.”

“It’s me, Mom” Elaine said, getting to the point. “I got laid off today”

“I’m sorry, dear” Elaine’s mother Abagail replied. “What are you going to do?”

“Well, I guess I’ll try to get another job.”

“You would not be in the situation if you were married”

Elaine sighed. She knew her mother would say that. “Don’t start that again.”

“Why don’t you call that Mr. Rolan? He’s still available.”

“He cheated on me, Mother. Twice, at least” Elaine almost shouted. “There’s no way I’m going to marry a three-timer.”

“So what” Abagail said. “You father cheated on me more times I can count, but he took good care of us. These days you can’t count on yourself. You need a man.”

Elaine was impatient to end the conversation. “Look, Mother, I have to go back to the office and collect my stuff. I’ll see you as soon as I can. Bye”

As Elaine hung up, she went back to the sofa and sat down. Her thoughts turned to Andrew Rulf, her former fiancé. "A child is a permanent decision, you can't get rid of a child," Mark argued. "What happens if the child is mentally or physically handicapped? We can't afford to care for a child with those intense special needs. Or worse, what if the child is a psychopath and tries to kill us in our sleep?"

152232211212.title: Arrival of a Deus ex machina

info.brief_description: Character is given a stone that gives him/her limitless wishes.(transform/gender swap/etc)
info.description:
In this story, the main character finds a mysterious stone/jewel that allows them to make limitless wishes. However, once a wish is made, it cannot be undone for 24 hours. Wishes can be made to add to that wish, but you cannot revert to the original state until 24 hours after the wish takes effect. No wishes can be made to change this. However, wishes can "improve" upon the previous wish. For example, if someone wished to be taller, they can wish to be even taller than that. Or, if someone wished to be more attractive, they can then alter their features to be even more attractive.

Wishes do not have to be made by saying "I wish..." As long as the character is holding the stone, their inner "wish" is granted. The wish must only contain the word wish, want, need, etc. For example, "I want to know what's going on," would be granted.

The character cannot wish to never lose the stone or never have the stone stolen. The character cannot have someone forget about the stone's existence. However, the character can wish for someone to forget about a wish.

Please no:
1) Sex in every chapter. Yes, you can describe body parts, and even talk about the events leading up to sex, but don't describe it every time it comes up. Also, I don't like "playing with my new body" chapters. Those are boring and pointless.
2) Killing.
3) Writing in the second person. Write from the third person, please. He, she, it, they.
4) You cannot wish to live forever, or for somebody to come back to life. Please stay within reason.
5) this isn't really a rule, but I dont really like when people wish for a new life or to completely alter their reality. Making some body change seem normal is fine, but don't give someone a new life. Also, if the change was accidental, don't always have the character react by loving it.

Thank you for adding, I'll send GP's for good additions. Also, I will edit, but mostly for grammar. Thank you, 100,000 chapter views and counting!
I am now holding a contest to encourage others to add to this story. At every fifty bench mark (ie 100, 150, 200) I will award that person 500 GP's if and only if it is a good, creative, and substantial addition. Thank you!

Congrats to JPEREZ4EVR for adding the 100th Chapter!!! Please email me and tell me which storylines you would most like to see continued!
